about: Hello, I am Masud. I'm deeply passionate about the intersection of robotics and artificial intelligence. name: Skip to main content
about: While studying for my Bachelor's in Software Engineering at Daffodil International University, I took an elective in machine learning and was instantly hooked. It was like I'd found a missing puzzle piece that brought all my interests together - math, statistics, programming and problem-solving. My first job was a Data Scientist under a professor of my university, where I was the youngest team member. But don't let that fool you - within my first year, I was leading a project. Numbers don't lie. This achievement still makes me proud. I've found that the drive and determination needed to tackle rough trails translates well into my professional life. It's allowed me to better understand how to handle complex data sets, and ultimately, how to turn raw data into actionable insights. If you're looking for someone who can make sense of big data and drive results for your company, I'd love to chat. You can reach me at salimsadman615@gmail.com. Let's talk about how we can turn your data into a competitive advantage.

On the other hand... ğŸ’» ğƒğšğ­ğš ğ’ğœğ¢ğğ§ğ­ğ¢ğ¬ğ­ğ¬ are knee-deep in notebooks, juggling experiments and analyses: ãƒ»Untitled.ipynb ãƒ»Untitled1.ipynb ãƒ»Untitled5.ipynb â€¦ and so on! #PromptEngineering #DataScience #MachineLearning #ai â€¦ more 501 reactions 501 13 comments â€¢ 7 reposts Like Comment Repost Send Jayed Bin Harez reposted this All things Javascript: JS, TypeScript, NodeJS, React, Angular, Vue, Svelte, Deno ASHFAQ AHMED â€¢ 3rd+ 1yr â€¢ #react 33 pages 1 / 33 0 279 reactions 279 3 comments â€¢ 36 reposts Like Comment Jayed Bin Harez reposted this Amit Sharma â€¢ 3rd+ Go High Level | Hubspot | CRM Developer | Automation Developer | Make.com | Zapier | Wordpress | AI bots | MERN Stack 1yr â€¢ ğŸŒŸ hashtag #React.js vs hashtag #Next.js: Which One Should You Choose? When building modern web applications, both React.js and Next.js are popular choices. However, each serves different purposes and offers unique benefits. Hereâ€™s a comparison to help you decide which is best for your project: ğŸ“Œ React.js: The Library for Building User Interfaces â€¢ Purpose: React.js is a JavaScript library focused on building reusable UI components. It handles the view layer of an application and allows developers to create dynamic, interactive web pages. â€¢ Flexibility: React.js provides the flexibility to build your applicationâ€™s architecture from scratch. You can choose your own routing, state management, and other tools. Community & Ecosystem**: With a vast community and rich ecosystem, React.js has countless libraries, tools, and resources available to extend its capabilities. â€¢ Client-Side Rendering (CSR): React primarily uses client-side rendering, where the entire application is loaded in the browser. This can sometimes lead to slower initial load times and potential SEO challenges. ğŸ“Œ Next.js: Framework of react â€¢ Purpose: Next.js is a framework built on top of React.js, designed to streamline the development process and enhance performance with out-of-the-box features like server-side rendering (SSR) and static site generation (SSG). â€¢ Built-In Features: Next.js offers built-in routing, image optimization, and API routes, reducing the need to configure these aspects manually. Itâ€™s an opinionated framework, making decisions for you to simplify development. â€¢ SEO & Performance: With SSR and SSG, Next.js significantly improves page load times and enhances SEO, making it ideal for content-heavy or e-commerce sites. â€¢ Fullstack Capabilities: Next.js also allows you to build fullstack applications with API routes, enabling you to create backend functionality within the same project. ğŸ”¥ When to Use React.js: 1) Flexibility Required: If you need full control over your projectâ€™s structure and want to pick your own tools and libraries, React.js is ideal. 2) Building Single-Page Applications (SPAs): React.js excels at creating SPAs where SEO isnâ€™t a primary concern. ğŸš€ When to Use Next.js: 1) SEO & Performance Focused: If youâ€™re building an application where SEO and fast load times are crucial, Next.js is the better choice. 2) Quick Development: With built-in features and conventions, Next.js helps you get projects up and running faster without sacrificing performance. âœ¨Conclusion:- Use React.js if you need maximum flexibility and prefer to build your application architecture from the ground up. Opt for Next.js if you want a more streamlined, performance-oriented framework with built-in features that make development faster and easier. Post credit to HM Daniyal get start your web development journey with W3Schools.com JavaScript Mastery Coding Ninjas #WebDevelopment #ReactJS #NextJS #FrontendDevelopment â€¦ more Next js Vs React js 10 pages 1 / 10 0 226 reactions 226 21 comments â€¢ 28 reposts Like Comment Repost Send Jayed Bin Harez reposted this Youness ZBAIR â€¢ 3rd+ Senior Full Stack Developer | PHP, Laravel, Vue.js, React.js, WordPress | Freelance Web Solutions Expert | #PHP #Laravel #VueJS #ReactJS #WordPress #FullStack #FreelanceDeveloper #WebDevelopment #Webflow 1yr â€¢ Fetching Data in ReactJS: Getting data in React can be done in several ways, depending on your needs. You can use `fetch` for a simple approach, `axios` for more advanced features, or `useEffect` with `async/await` to manage side effects in functional components. For real-time data, consider WebSockets or libraries like `SWR` and `React Query` for caching and background data syncing. ğŸ› ï¸ #ReactJS #WebDevelopment #FetchData #APIs #JavaScript #FrontendDev #Programming #SoftwareDevelopment #TechTips #ReactHooks #WebTech #DeveloperLife #TechStack #DevCommunity â€¦ more ways to fetch data in react js 7 pages 1 / 7 0 35 reactions 35 1 comment â€¢ 2 reposts Like Comment Repost Send Jayed Bin Harez reposted this Muhammad Zubair â€¢ 3rd+

experience.title: HTML5 Do's and Don'ts ğŸ“
experience.company: HTML5 is the backbone of modern web development, providing the structure for web pages and enabling powerful features like multimedia, offline storage, and responsive design. To make the most of HTML5 and ensure that your code is both effective and future-proof, it's essential to follow best practices and avoid common pitfalls.

experience.title: - Use Semantic Elements: Utilize `<header>`, `<footer>`, `<article>`, `<section>`, and other semantic tags to structure your content meaningfully. This improves accessibility and SEO.
- Validate Your Code: Regularly validate your HTML to catch errors early and ensure cross-browser compatibility.
- Optimize Media: Use the latest HTML5 tags like `<video>` and `<audio>` with appropriate fallbacks for older browsers, and always optimize media files for faster loading.
- Use Alt Attributes: Always provide `alt` attributes for images to improve accessibility for users with disabilities and ensure better SEO.
- Avoid Inline Styles: Refrain from using inline styles in your HTML. Instead, use external CSS to maintain a clean, organized codebase.
- Donâ€™t Overuse Divs: While `<div>` is versatile, overusing it can lead to bloated and confusing code. Stick to semantic elements wherever possible.
- Avoid Deprecated Tags: Steer clear of old, deprecated tags like `<font>` and `<center>`. Stick to modern alternatives that adhere to HTML5 standards.
- Donâ€™t Neglect Accessibility: Always consider accessibility when designing your HTML structure. Use ARIA roles and attributes to enhance the user experience for all visitors.
experience.company: By following these HTML5 do's and don'ts, you can create web pages that are not only functional but also future-proof, accessible, and maintainable.
